data.title: Barbra Streisand says she's not a diva - she's a director : It's Been a Minute
data.meta_description: The season of the celebrity memoir is upon us. In just the past few months Britney Spears, Jada Pinkett Smith, Kerry Washington, and more have showered us with bombshells and revelations about their origin stories and private lives. Despite those heavy hitters and the crowded field they occupy, the celebrity memoir our host Brittany Luse coveted most is that of the singular Ms. Barbra Streisand. Brittany sits down with Barbra to talk about her new memoir, My Name is Barbra, her struggle to take creative control of her work, and what legacy she wants to leave behind.
data.text:
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

BRITTANY LUSE, HOST:

Hey, hey. I'm Brittany Luse, and you're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, a show where we talk about what's going on in our culture and why it doesn't happen by accident. And today, an interview I feel like I have been preparing my whole life for. Ms. Barbra Streisand, welcome to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE. It is a pleasure to have you.

BARBRA STREISAND: Thank you so much for having me.

LUSE: I cannot even front. I am a Barbra fangirl, so I was beyond thrilled to sit down with her to talk about her new memoir called "My Name Is Barbra." Now, Ms. Streisand is one of the original multihyphenates. She really does it all and has every letter of EGOT to prove it. And even though most people know her first and foremost for her beautiful and singular voice...

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "FUNNY GIRL")

STREISAND: (As Fanny Brice, singing) Don't bring around a cloud to rain on my parade.

LUSE: ...Singing isn't really her passion.

STREISAND: I didn't start out to be a singer. I just desperately wanted to be an actress, and I couldn't get a job.

LUSE: She parlayed her singing stardom into an acting career with iconic movies like "Funny Girl" and "The Way We Were," and then that turned into a desire to get behind the camera and direct for films like "Yentl" and "The Prince Of Tides."

STREISAND: I love the mechanisms of making films. What are the camera moves? What character do I focus on at this moment then at that moment? How do I indicate this song? How does it photograph? I mean, I love having lots to concentrate on.

LUSE: That hunger to act on her vision and her desire for artistic control is what drives everything Barbra has done. But she says every bit of that control was hard won.

STREISAND: You know, you can't dress like that or you can't sing songs like that or you should become more commercial so that you would sell more records or whatever. I just never understood it.

LUSE: Barbara is even more impressive when you look at the timing of it all. She founded her first production company years before American women could even open up a credit card without their husband. I chatted with the Ms. Streisand about her memoir, her incredible life and what it meant to take the reins.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: Your memoir, "My Name Is Barbara," is coming out. But something I noticed grabbed me as soon as I opened up, like...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...The prologue. The first...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...Page of your book details some of the harshest things your critics have said about you over the years. And it wasn't where I was expecting the book would start. And a few pages later, you say (reading) I'm scared that after six decades of people making up stories about me, I'm going to tell the truth, and nobody is going to believe it. What...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...About the real you did you think people would find so unbelievable?

STREISAND: I mean, I never read the books about me when I was doing this book. I had to hire a researcher to look me up because I just never read those things. But I was told about the stories about me, you know. When I tried to say early in my career but that's not true, it didn't matter. The myths keep getting perpetuated.

LUSE: You say these myths. What kind of myths are we talking about? What were these stories that were out there about you that were untrue?

STREISAND: Something about putting petals - that I - that petals had to follow me, you know? Like, making me into a diva. I'm not a diva, you know what I mean? I'm from Brooklyn. Divas, I don't think come from Brooklyn.

LUSE: Everybody knows your voice, of course. And, I mean, you know, we're thinking about your music career. We're talking over 50 albums, and you are known as one of the greatest performers of all time. But I also think of you as one of the greatest image makers of all time. And I think that your work as a director really speaks to that. And that's what I really want to focus on today. I mean, your directing career officially began in 1983 with "Yentl," but you seem to have a director's mind from the beginning of your career as it's unfolding in your book.

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: What was the moment that made you realize that your opinions could shape an overall project for the better?

STREISAND: Wow. That's a lovely thing to say about me. But it is true, I think. I just was always visualizing things in my head. When I first had to, you know, make a living by singing when I got the job on stage in "I Can Get It For You Wholesale," my first Broadway show, and I did an audition, and I told them I want to sit in a chair...

LUSE: Right.

STREISAND: ...Because first of all, I'm nervous. And being nervous, I'd like to sit in a chair. But second of all, that's how I imagined her, the character, Miss Marmelstein, singing her song.

(SOUNDBITE OF PLAY, "I CAN GET IT FOR YOU WHOLESALE")

STREISAND: (As Miss Marmelstein, singing) Nobody calls me hey, baby doll...

UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #1: (As character) Miss Marmelstein.

STREISAND: (As Miss Marmelstein, singing) ...Or honey dear...

UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #2: (As character) Miss Marmelstein.

STREISAND: (As Miss Marmelstein, singing) ...Or sweetie pie.

UNIDENTIFIED ACTORS: (As characters) Miss Marmelstein.

LUSE: She was a secretary, right?

STREISAND: She was a secretary. Secretarial chairs have wheels, so it would be funny, I knew, to roll around in that chair. And then as soon as we start rehearsals, they say, well, now we're going to stage it. Stage it how? And that was with lots of people on the stage walking back and forth with papers in their hands. It just didn't feel right, do you see what I mean? One was staged and felt uncomfortable, the other way felt honest that that song would come from her sitting in what she's comfortable in.

LUSE: It's like not just thinking about the song that you had to sing or thinking about that detail about the character, like, her profession...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...As just a detail, thinking about...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...How to bring all of those things together to make the story truer.

STREISAND: Exactly. It just felt right.

LUSE: But I want to fast-forward from this point where you're earlier in your career, and you are realizing that you can visualize a piece in full. And I want to talk about your directorial debut. "Yentl" was your dream project, and we all know that it went on to be a huge success, but it took over a decade to get made, partially because...

STREISAND: Fifteen years. Yeah.

LUSE: Fifteen years.

STREISAND: Yeah. It's hard.

LUSE: I mean, that's no cakewalk.

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: And there were so many points, as you point out in the book, where you could have given up. Some people told you that you should have given up, but you didn't. And so we all know it now to be this huge success, but it took so long to get made. And part of that was because some of the executives who passed on this project told you that it was too Jewish of a story to be marketable, even if the executives themselves were Jewish. You know, looking back, what do you think of that comment, too Jewish? What do you think that comment really meant, and what did you think of it at the time?

STREISAND: Well, the Jewish population then and now was very small in terms of the United States population or the world population, after World War II, especially. The dislike, the hatred, whatever you want to call it. Even those - I just read the - I can't tell you the real names of the heads of studios, you know, from Warner Brothers. They all had to change their name to be sort of less Jewish, you know?

LUSE: To be, like, more anglicized or American...

STREISAND: Yes. Exactly.

LUSE: ...Sounding.

STREISAND: Exactly. So I think they were afraid to be that, the other, the one that was hounded in Europe, you know, trying to raise themselves up, become more anglicized. Yeah.

LUSE: The way you're describing it now, you sound like you have an understanding about it, but I wonder, was it infuriating to you at the time? Like, were you ever insulted, or did you have sort of the same even-handedness in thinking about it where you could - you were disappointed that you couldn't get your project made, but you had some insight as to where they were coming from? How did you see it then?

STREISAND: Yeah. I think so. I mean, again, when I went to the studios with this little, short story, "Yentl The Yeshiva Boy," my agent, when I found out he never told me about that offer to do something with that story, I asked, why wouldn't you tell me what was offered to me? Well, he says, you know, you just played a Jewish girl in "Funny Girl," and so you don't want to play a Jewish boy, do you? You know, that kind of thing. It was like, but that's not for you to tell me.

LUSE: Right.

STREISAND: This story interested me because it was about gender inequality. That a woman couldn't study. You know what that feeling is? You - to be you, you became what you wanted to be. I became what I wanted to be, but I don't want somebody telling me what I can't be.

LUSE: It's like some of the things that you saw Yentl up against in her life in the story, you could also...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...See some of those same forces at work in your own life with people telling you no.

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: I recently rewatched it in preparing to talk to you today, and I was reminded how beautiful a film it is, but also, how sophisticated the gender commentary in the film is and how ahead of its time it was. The ending, of course, is so radical because Yentl chooses the intellectual connection and stimulation over conventional romance, which, I mean, it felt transgressive for me to watch it when I rewatched it a couple of days ago, so I can imagine it felt that way 40 years ago. But, you know, something I also noticed this time around when I was watching the film was how in passing as a man, Yentl is sometimes seduced by all the trappings that come along with a man's life, specifically a dutiful wife and a beautiful home without having to do the cooking and the cleaning and the decorating...

STREISAND: That's right.

LUSE: ...You know?

STREISAND: That's right.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "YENTL")

UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #3: (As character) More noodles? They're your favorite.

STREISAND: (As Yentl) How do you know?

UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR #3: (As character) You told me last week at dinner.

LUSE: I was watching it...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...And I was thinking, this movie is still what the girls need today. Like...

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: ...This movie is still, like - it's still so relevant.

STREISAND: We haven't progressed in all those years. Oh, my God.

LUSE: Yeah. Could you have imagined that the gender commentary in "Yentl" would still be so relevant in 2023?

STREISAND: I didn't imagine that. I mean, I was just being in the moment, you know? It just shows you how slow it's taken, how many years it's taken, to be a woman with opinions and have that be OK now.

LUSE: Coming up, Barbra Streisand on what it means to have control over her work and her anxiety over her legacy. Stick around.

I saw this clip. I don't know if you're aware of this 'cause...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...I don't know how tapped in you try to stay to what people are saying about you...

STREISAND: Oh, tell...

LUSE: ...Online...

STREISAND: ...Me. No, no, I don't know.

LUSE: ...But there's this clip of you that has been going around on social media. It's a clip of you in costume and in scene in "Yentl," directing the scene between Yentl and Avigdor with the reveal. And Avigdor is yelling. Mandy Patinkin is yelling...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...And screaming...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...And moving around...

STREISAND: Right, right, right, right.

LUSE: ...And you are directing and giving directions to the camera operator...

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

MANDY PATINKIN: (As Avigdor) This is my - mine. This is my doing?

STREISAND: (As Yentl) It was your idea.

Just get a little bit of this.

PATINKIN: (As Avigdor) Mine?

STREISAND: (As Yentl) It was your idea.

PATINKIN: (As Avigdor) Mine?

STREISAND: (As Yentl) Yes.

LUSE: ...And giving directions to Mandy while...

STREISAND: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah.

LUSE: ...You are acting, and...

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: ...I mean, talk to me about how you think about being in those modes and how you think about them.

STREISAND: Being an actress first, I would think, you know, why are you stopping just to powder somebody's nose or fix their hair for a minute? When you're a director, you can control that. I always saw the whole. I never just saw my part. I saw the whole. What is the picture trying to say? You know, how do you tell the story? That was what was interesting to me, not just being an actress.

LUSE: I've been thinking a lot about your directing career and how it fits into, you know, more women becoming directors in Hollywood over time and how people's misperceptions about women can kind of keep us from being able to reach our fullest potential or from even being seen properly and clearly by other people. You mentioned that so many people associate you with divadom (ph).

STREISAND: Divadom.

LUSE: Yes.

STREISAND: That's funny. That's not who I am. What is that about people that want to believe that? Maybe they're projecting their own wishes?

LUSE: That actually is a question that I have. I mean, you know, I'm thinking about your career and you directed, acted with or were friends with or were admired by many of the male icons in Hollywood across eras - Marlon Brando, Omar Sharif, William Wyler, Robert Redford. And, you know, they are - were - all hard workers - exacting, talented, high standards. But you're the person who's remembered as the diva. And...

STREISAND: Yeah, yeah, yeah. That's interesting. Yeah.

LUSE: They may have...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...Been divas, too. I don't know. You might know better than me. But that name only sticks to women. And I know that you've been asked before...

STREISAND: Wow. No, that's perceptive. Yeah.

LUSE: I mean, I know you've been asked before why someone might say that about you, but I want to know that question that you're getting at. I want to know, what does our culture get out of placing that diva stereotype onto successful women?

STREISAND: I think there's a - I don't know if I talked about this in my book, about my theory about the cave man.

LUSE: I think you did put it in the book.

STREISAND: Oh, good. I thought, why are men sometimes frightened by a woman's power? And I just came up with this image of the cave man before language, you know? They hump each other, whatever, she gets pregnant. There's no word for pregnant. He has to be totally blown away by that, that she can reproduce life. But also, if she could give life, she could take it away, perhaps. And it's a fear, a fear of women and the awe of women.

LUSE: I see your legacy as a producer and director when I look at an artist like Beyonce, who through her company, Parkwood Entertainment, has funded, produced and directed multiple films, similar to what you've done with Barwood Films, your production company. And, you know, we all know about your influence on the industry as a performer. But I wonder, how do you see your influence on the entertainment industry as a businesswoman?

STREISAND: I don't think I do, really.

LUSE: What do you mean?

STREISAND: It was only sort of expressions of - I just never thought about, really, the business aspect. I just thought about it from the control aspect.

LUSE: That is something that came up again and again and again in the book.

STREISAND: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.

LUSE: I think at the end of one chapter just said, you know, I have to be in control.

STREISAND: Right, I have to - I'm a director, that's right. The first time I got a contract, again, I wanted to be an actress, so it didn't matter to me if I got a record contract to sing. My manager, Marty Erlichman, who became my manager when I was 19, and, you know, he brought Columbia Records down to see me. And they wanted to sign me. I said to Marty, I don't care what I get paid, I just want to be able to control my work, what songs I sing. What's the cover of the album look like? What are the details? I have to control that. At the time - what is that, 60 years ago, I think? - they were suggesting I call my album "Sweet And Saucy Streisand."

LUSE: (Laughter) I'm sorry.

STREISAND: You know what I mean?

LUSE: Yes.

STREISAND: And probably wanted a picture of me smiling on the cover. I never used to smile much in those days. But I wanted to control that, and I got that. You know, I was able to call my album "The Barbra Streisand Album" because I said, that's what it is. If they see me on television, it's the girl that was on television. And I think her name was, I don't know, funny...

LUSE: Saucy or something.

STREISAND: You know?

(LAUGHTER)

STREISAND: And so I was able to have that, you see? That's what was important to me.

LUSE: Was control.

STREISAND: Control of my work. There was another album. I never liked to be photographed and taken - I never liked to have pictures taken and album covers. So I had had some extra pictures left over from a photographer that took me to the beach in Chicago when I was 18.

LUSE: Yes.

STREISAND: And I said, you know, let me see the pictures and so forth. And I thought later on, when I needed an album cover for "People," the album "People," I said, here, let's use this picture of my back. I was just looking at the ocean. It's amazing how emotions can figure into a flat piece of paper. You know, the photograph, if it's right, captures the emotion I feel even on your back. And I said, that's the cover I'd like. And they said, you can't do that. You can't have a picture of your back, you know, it won't sell.

LUSE: Yeah.

STREISAND: Whatever. I said, well, that's the picture I want, and it became a Grammy Award-winning cover.

LUSE: You say all this about control. I wonder, do you see this book as a form of control over your legacy?

STREISAND: Yes. Yes (laughter).

LUSE: Like something like the ultimate director's cut of your life?

(LAUGHTER)

STREISAND: Very well-said, very well-put. Yeah, it is.

LUSE: I got one more question I want to ask you.

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: There is this 1991 interview...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...On "60 Minutes." You were talking to Mike Wallace. We don't have to get into that because that could be a whole conversation in and of itself...

STREISAND: By itself.

LUSE: ...Just that interview (laughter). But there's this moment, I was watching it - rewatching it recently, and there's this moment in the conversation where you look back on your performance with Judy Garland on TV in 1963.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE JUDY GARLAND SHOW")

JUDY GARLAND: (Singing) Forget your troubles.

STREISAND: (Singing) Happy days.

GARLAND: (Singing) Come on, get happy.

STREISAND: (Singing) Are here again.

LUSE: And you're remembering how surprised you were that Judy's hands were shaking with nerves...

STREISAND: Right, right.

LUSE: ...When she held your hand. And you said that you didn't understand her fear at the time.

STREISAND: Right.

LUSE: But in '91, at 48, in your late 40s, you understood Judy was afraid of falling out of public favor, of being forgotten, becoming obsolete.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "60 MINUTES")

STREISAND: It's like going out after being in the business 30 years...

MIKE WALLACE: Yeah.

STREISAND: ...You know, it's like everybody's ready to say she's going downhill or her career is over or they want it to be over. Not the public, mind you.

LUSE: And you seem to be processing and understanding Judy's perspective and that fear at the time in that interview in 1991. But now you're 81, and your book doesn't have any of that anxiety.

STREISAND: Really?

LUSE: You seem pleased with your life.

STREISAND: Why do you think it took me so long to write it? Ten years, because I have that same anxiety. You know, I do, I understand what she was shaking about. I didn't understand it when I was 21.

LUSE: Right.

STREISAND: And I think she was about 42. Almost double my age.

LUSE: Right.

STREISAND: And I loved her. I didn't grow up knowing her, knowing her work, but we became friends. And her vulnerability, you know, I became like her, in a sense. Very - well, I...

LUSE: You mean vulnerable over time? You mean you became vulnerable in that way over time?

STREISAND: Over time. Over - more vulnerable, even, than I was. Yeah. You know, the fear of forgetting the words, not being able to sing till there was such a thing as teleprompters. The fear of letting down the audience. Was I good enough? Was my voice good enough? Was - I just had to do concerts because I had, you know, I had to pay the rent...

LUSE: Right.

STREISAND: ...And my flowers and, you know, live the way I wanted to live. But I never really enjoyed performing after a certain time.

LUSE: I wonder though, like, you know, your book, you said it took a while to write and you waited...

STREISAND: Yeah.

LUSE: ...So long to write it, but your book, in reading it, and especially in the later chapters and even in your reflections earlier on, you seem so pleased with your life. I wonder what shifted between 48 and 81 that got you to this place of contentment?

STREISAND: Well, finding the right partner, my husband, you know. Because men were afraid of me, too. I think it takes a strong man to say to me, I'm taking you home. I was like, huh? You know?

LUSE: I read in the book, the night you met your husband...

STREISAND: That's right.

LUSE: ...He said, you're done working for the day?

STREISAND: (Laughter).

LUSE: I'm coming over. We're going to talk.

(LAUGHTER)

STREISAND: I know, I had...

LUSE: I mean, I could see how a partner is part of it, but I mean, within you, what shifted? I'm trying to get some secrets, some advice, some - what's to come? Like, what changed within you - happened between those two points in time that got you to the point where you feel this contentment and you were ready to look back in this way?

STREISAND: Yeah. I wasn't ready for the longest time. I thought I had more to do. But then I came to a point where I think what I did was enough. And then you say, you know, OK, let me just live my life. Let me see what that is, you know?

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: Well, Ms. Streisand, thank you so much for joining me today. It was a pleasure to have you.

STREISAND: Oh, you're such a wonderful interviewer.

LUSE: Thank you. Thank you.

STREISAND: No, really. You're very warm and very easy to talk to. You're my first interview.

LUSE: You're a busy woman, so I'm glad we could get on your schedule. But, Ms. Streisand, thank you so much. Thank you so much.

STREISAND: And thank you. I really appreciate you.

LUSE: Thanks again to Barbra Streisand. Her memoir, "My Name Is Barbra," is out now.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: This episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by...

BARTON GIRDWOOD, BYLINE: Barton Girdwood.

ALEXIS WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Alexis Williams.

LIAM MCBAIN, BYLINE: Liam McBain.

COREY ANTONIO ROSE, BYLINE: Corey Antonio Rose.

LUSE: This episode was edited by...

JESSICA PLACZEK, BYLINE: Jessica Placzek.

BILAL QURESHI, BYLINE: Bilal Qureshi.

LUSE: Engineering support came from...

PATRICK MURRAY, BYLINE: Patrick Murray.

MAGGIE LUTHAR, BYLINE: Maggie Luthar.

LUSE: Our executive producer is...

VERALYN WILLIAMS, BYLINE: Veralyn Williams.

LUSE: Our VP of programming is...

YOLANDA SANGWENI, BYLINE: Yolanda Sangweni.

LUSE: Our senior VP of programming is...

ANYA GRUNDMANN, BYLINE: Anya Grundmann.

LUSE: All right. That's all for this episode of IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Brittany Luse. Talk soon.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
